title: Israel Denies Over 100 NGOs Aid Delivery to Palestinians, Sparks Outcry
snippets: More than 100 aid organisations say they are increasingly being told they are "not authorised" to deliver aid.
Mass outcry from aid groups as Israel continues to block millions of dollars in aid supplies to starving Palestinians.

More than 100 international NGOs sign letter saying more than 60 requests to bring in food, water and items for shelter were denied by authorities in July alone

We are just receiving pictures via the wires from inside Nasser Medical Complex, a hospital in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.
titles: Humanitarian groups call on Israel to end 'weaponisation of aid' in Gaza
More than 100 groups blast Israel’s ‘weaponisation of aid’ as Gaza starves
NGOs call for end to Israel’s ‘weaponisation’ of aid – Middle East crisis live
summary: Over 100 international NGOs have reported being denied authorization by Israeli authorities to deliver crucial aid, including food, water, and shelter items, to Palestinians. In July alone, more than 60 requests were rejected. This situation has sparked significant concern among aid organizations, as evidenced by a collective letter and the mass outcry against the blockade of millions of dollars in aid. Recent images from Nasser Medical Complex in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, highlight the dire situation on the ground.

title: UK Economy Grows 0.3% in Q2, Exceeding Forecasts but Slows Down
snippets: The economy expanded by 0.3% between April to June period, ahead of economists' expectations.
Figure marks a sharp slowdown from 0.7% expansion in first three months of the year

The UK economy fared better than expected in the second quarter, bringing some relief for Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves but raising the bar to further interest-rate cuts from the Bank of England.
titles: UK economic growth slows but beats forecasts
UK economic growth slows in second quarter
UK Economy Grew Faster-Than-Forecast 0.3% in Second Quarter
summary: The UK economy grew by 0.3% in the April to June period, surpassing economists' forecasts but showing a deceleration from the 0.7% growth in the first quarter. This performance, better than anticipated, provides some support for Chancellor Rachel Reeves, yet it complicates potential for further interest-rate reductions by the Bank of England.

This decision came after a US composer's copyright claim was rejected due to insufficient evidence of copyright infringement.

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder medication is linked to significantly lower risk of suicidal behaviours, substance misuse, transport accidents and criminality, according to a
titles: ADHD drugs cut risk of suicide, car accidents and criminality, study suggests
ADHD drugs reduce risk of criminal behaviour, drug abuse and accidents

summary: A study in Sweden involving 150,000 individuals with ADHD found that medications for the condition not only improve symptoms but also significantly reduce the risks of substance misuse, suicidal behaviors, transport accidents, and criminality. This research highlights the broader benefits of ADHD drugs beyond their primary purpose of managing the disorder's immediate symptoms.

Additionally, Trump reassured European leaders about the discussions with Putin, emphasizing a focus on achieving a ceasefire and the possibility of a meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy.

title: Court Upholds Trump's Freeze on Foreign Aid Funds

Critics argue President Trump has overstepped his constitutional authority by slashing congressionally approved aid.
titles: President Trump can continue to withhold billions in foreign aid, court rules
US appeals court lets Trump slash billions in foreign aid
summary: A federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that President Trump's administration can continue to freeze or terminate billions of dollars in congressionally approved foreign aid. Critics claim this action oversteps his constitutional authority. This decision marks a victory for the Trump administration in its handling of foreign aid funds.

Detained since December 2020, his trial has drawn international concern, with Western nations and rights groups demanding his release. The trial's closing arguments were delayed due to Hong Kong issuing its highest-level weather warning.

title: PSG Wins UEFA Super Cup, Defeats Tottenham on Penalties

Tottenham heartbreak as PSG win Super Cup on penalties after late collapse

The game, held in Udine, saw PSG score two late goals to force a shootout, ultimately claiming their first European trophy of the season and their fifth trophy of 2025.

title: NY Attorney General Sues Zelle Banks Over $1B Fraud Allegations
snippets: New York Attorney General Letitia James’ office picked up the lawsuit after the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau dropped a similar one in March.

New York Attorney General Letitia James is suing the banks behind Zelle over claims that their payment platform enabled “massive amounts of fraud” that caused customers to lose more than $1 billion between 2017 and 2023. In the lawsuit, James alleges Zelle was rushed to market, resulting in a design
titles: New York Sues Zelle—What To Know About Alleged $1 Billion Scams Over The App
New York claims Zelle’s shoddy security enabled a billion dollars in scams
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James is suing the banks responsible for Zelle, alleging the payment platform facilitated over $1 billion in customer fraud from 2017 to 2023. The lawsuit claims Zelle was prematurely launched, leading to its flawed design that enabled fraud. This legal action follows the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau dropping a similar case in March.

The service aims to expand to at least 2,300 locations by the end of the year.

title: Perplexity Offers $34.5B for Chrome After Google Monopoly Ruling

summary: US antitrust officials, after finding Google guilty of monopolizing the search market, suggested the company sell its Chrome browser. Perplexity, known for its AI browser Comet, has made an unsolicited offer of $34.5 billion to purchase Chrome from Google.

title: Soybean Plants Can Inherit Stress Responses, Study Finds
snippets: When soybean plants survive attacks from insects and periods of drought, they remember. While plants don't remember in the way animals do, research out of the Arkansas Agricultural Experiment Station shows that soybean plants can pass on adaptive responses to stress—like those caused by hungry insec
titles: Soybeans seem to inherit the bad memories of their parents
summary: Research from the Arkansas Agricultural Experiment Station reveals that soybean plants can inherit adaptive stress responses to threats such as insect attacks and drought. This means that, although plants do not have memories like animals, they can transfer their experiences of stress to their offspring, enabling future generations to better withstand similar challenges.

title: Climate Change Added 2°C to Nordic Heatwave, Impacting Health and Ecosystems
snippets: Human-caused climate change made a recent Nordic heatwave about 2C hotter, putting a strain on healthcare, ecosystems and indigenous Sami reindeer herders in a region ill-equipped for such events, researchers said on Thursday.
titles: Climate change made Nordic heatwave 2C hotter: study
summary: Researchers have determined that human-caused climate change increased the temperature of a recent Nordic heatwave by approximately 2°C. This exacerbation has impacted healthcare, ecosystems, and indigenous Sami reindeer herders in an area not well-prepared for such extreme weather conditions.

title: Colorado Rabbits with Horn-Like Growths Due to Common Virus, No Alarm Needed
snippets: A group of rabbits in Colorado with grotesque, hornlike growths may seem straight out of a low-budget horror film, but scientists say there's no reason to be spooked—the furry creatures merely have a relatively common virus.
titles: Rabbits with 'horns' in Colorado are being called 'Frankenstein bunnies.' Here's why
summary: In Colorado, rabbits have been observed with unusual, horn-like growths, sparking interest and concern. However, scientists have identified these growths as symptoms of a relatively common virus affecting the animals. They assure the public there is no cause for alarm regarding these peculiar appearances.

title: Scientists Uncover How Amaranth Plants Resist Zinc Toxicity
snippets: Scientists from Immanuel Kant Baltic Federal University, together with researchers from St. Petersburg State University and K.A.Timiryazev Institute of Plant Physiology RAS, have defined key changes in the metabolism of amaranth plants that help them to resist the toxic influence of zinc.
titles: Sugars and organic acids save amaranth from zinc poisoning
summary: Researchers from Immanuel Kant Baltic Federal University, St. Petersburg State University, and K.A.Timiryazev Institute of Plant Physiology RAS have identified significant metabolic adjustments in amaranth plants that enable them to withstand the toxic effects of zinc. This discovery contributes to the understanding of plant resilience to heavy metal stress.

title: Study Analyzes Astrobiology Portrayal 1996-2024
snippets: Astrobiology poses fundamental questions about life in the universe: How did it emerge? Is there life beyond Earth? In a recently published study in PLOS One, researchers from Leiden University investigated how the field was portrayed in the public sphere from 1996 to 2024 by shining light on what s
titles: Speculations about extraterrestrial life peak in news articles—and in scientist quotes
summary: A study published in PLOS One by Leiden University researchers analyzed the public portrayal of astrobiology from 1996 to 2024. The study focused on understanding the field's key questions, such as the origins of life and the possibility of extraterrestrial existence.

title: AI Tool HEAT-ML Identifies Safe Zones in Fusion Reactors to Boost Safety
snippets: Scientists have developed a lightning-fast AI tool called HEAT-ML that can spot hidden “safe zones” inside a fusion reactor where parts are protected from blistering plasma heat. Finding these areas, known as magnetic shadows, is key to keeping reactors running safely and moving fusion energy closer
titles: AI finds hidden safe zones inside a fusion reactor
summary: Scientists have created HEAT-ML, an AI tool designed to identify "safe zones" or "magnetic shadows" within fusion reactors. These zones are crucial for protecting reactor parts from extreme plasma heat, thereby enhancing reactor safety and advancing fusion energy technology. This development represents a significant step towards the operational efficiency and longevity of fusion reactors.

title: Otter Habits May Aid in Detecting Environmental Health Risks
snippets: North American river otters have terrible hygiene when it comes to their food. They eat, play and defecate in the same place. But their unhealthy habits make them ideal for detecting future health threats in the environment, according to scientists.
titles: How river otters' terrible food hygiene benefits ecosystem health monitoring
summary: Scientists have found that North American river otters exhibit poor hygiene habits by eating, playing, and defecating in the same area. Despite this, researchers believe these habits make otters well-suited for detecting potential health risks in the environment. This behavior could help scientists monitor and identify future health threats.

titles: Apple’s plan for AI could make Siri the animated center of your smart home

title: UC Berkeley Study: Oxytocin Key to Fast Friendship Formation
snippets: UC Berkeley scientists found oxytocin is key for quickly forming strong friendships, but less critical for mate bonds. In prairie voles, a lack of oxytocin receptors delayed bonding and reduced partner selectivity, changing how the brain releases oxytocin and affecting social behavior.
titles: The surprising brain chemistry behind instant friendships
summary: UC Berkeley researchers discovered that oxytocin plays a crucial role in quickly developing strong friendships, though it's less important for creating mate bonds. In studies with prairie voles, the absence of oxytocin receptors led to slower bonding and less selectivity in choosing partners. This finding highlights how oxytocin influences brain activity and social interactions.
